nodes.text: A decision tree based machine learning model can classify and predict diabetes in patients using the Pima Indians dataset
Decision tree classification is an appropriate method for medical diagnosis tasks because it produces interpretable if-then rules and handles classification problems
We used the Pima Indians Diabetes Database containing 768 instances and 9 attributes to train and test the model
Data preprocessing removed rows with zero values in BloodPressure, BMI, or Glucose because zeros were treated as measurement errors and 35 samples had zero values
The model was implemented in Python using Pandas for data handling and scikit-learn DecisionTreeClassifier, with visualization of the trained tree
Decision trees can partition datasets by maximizing information gain and can use entropy, Gini, or classification error as heterogeneity measures
The dataset was split into training and testing subsets in three experiments: 70/30, 50/50, and 30/70
Exploratory data analysis revealed outliers and impossible zero values for physiologic measures indicating data quality issues
Experiment 1: training 70% and testing 30% produced a set of accuracy and classification report metrics (visualized in figures)
Experiment 2: training 50% and testing 50% achieved the best reported accuracy of 0.71 for this study
Experiment 3: training 30% and testing 70% produced lower accuracy estimates compared to larger training splits
Increasing the proportion of data used for training improves the accuracy estimate of the decision tree model in this dataset
Conclusion: Decision tree analysis is a useful predictive modeling tool for diabetes classification offering fast training, intuitive rules, nonparametric modeling, and competitive accuracy
Limitation: The model requires further clinical consultation and more accurate diagnosis since some dataset features may be unavailable to users and data quality issues remain
